Ethanol electro-oxidation using cadmium-doped cobalt/carbon nanoparticles as novel non precious electrocatalyst Nasser A.M. Barakat a b ⁎ Mohammad A. Abdelkareem b Hak Yong Kim a ⁎ a Organic Materials and Fiber Engineering Department, Chonbuk National University, Jeonju 561-756, Republic of Korea b Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Minia University, El-Minia, Egypt ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Organic Materials and Fiber Engineering Department, Chonbuk National University, Jeonju 561-756, Republic of Korea. Tel.: +82 632702363; fax: +82 632702348. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The study introduces Co-mainly-based material as EOR electrocatalyst. ► Cd-doped Co nanoparticles encapsulated in graphite shell are introduced. ► The introduced NPs can be effectively used as electrocatalyst in ethanol oxidation. ► The introduced NPs reveal low onset potential and high current densities. Novel electrocatalyst based on non precious metals (Co and Cd) is introduced to be used as anode in the ethanol fuel cells. Cd-doped Cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated in graphite shell have been synthesized using simple sol–gel technique. The introduced electrocatalyst can be prepared from a sol–gel composed of cadmium acetate, cobalt acetate and poly(vinyl alcohol) based on the polycondensation possibility of the acetates. Grinding and calcination in Ar atmosphere of the prepared gel leads to produce Cd-doped Co nanoparticles encapsulated in a thin graphite layer. High current density (70mAcm−2) and considerably low onset potential (∼585mV vs. NHE) were obtained when the synthesized nanoparticles have been exploited as electrocatalyst for ethanol (concentration 1M) oxidation in basic media (1M KOH). Considering that the introduced nanoparticles composed of non precious metals and the obtained electrochemical results are satisfactory, the introduced study might open new avenues to the cobalt-based nanostructures to be used as novel electrocatalysts in the fuel cells applications. Keywords Direct ethanol fuel cells Non precious catalysts Cadmium-doped cobalt Sol–gel 1 Introduction Methanol, ethanol and 2-propanol are the main alcohols used directly as fuels in the direct alcohols fuel cells (DAFCs). Methanol is nonrenewable, volatile and a flammable substance; moreover it has a high toxicity. The use of methanol may result in major issues if applied to portable devices. On the other hand, ethanol is less toxic and has a higher energy density compared to methanol. Methanol and ethanol have energy densities of 6.09 and 8.00kWhkg−1, respectively [1]. Ethanol can be also produced from agricultural bioprocesses and is considered a renewable energy [2]. Electrochemically, the direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have several disadvantages. The issues with DMFCs are their sluggish reaction kinetics for methanol oxidation, methanol crossover through Nafion membranes to the oxygen electrode and anode poisoning by strongly adsorbed intermediates (mainly CO) [3]. Ethanol is well known for having a lower crossover rate and affecting cathode performance less severely than methanol because of its smaller permeability through the Nafion membrane and its slower electrochemical oxidation kinetics on the Pt/C cathode [3,4]. Accordingly, ethanol is a good fuel choice for overcoming the problems with methanol. Moreover, the direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs) show better polarization characteristics in alkaline media, using alkali electrolytes allows for a greater possibility for application of non-noble and less expensive metal catalysts. At present, almost all pre-commercial low-temperature fuel cells use Pt-based electrocatalysts [5–8]. Consequently, the manufacturing cost is relatively high which constrains wide applications. Moreover, the catalyst poisoning by CO or CHO species is another real problem facing most of the Pt-based electrocatalysts [9–11]. Compared to the precious metals, transition metals are abundant and cheap. Although, among the transition metals, cobalt has a well known catalytic activity in many chemical reactions, cobalt was not used as a main catalyst in the DAFCs due to the low performance. However, it is used as a co-catalyst to annihilate the Pt poisoning. Pt–Co alloys have been found to be excellent CO-tolerant catalysts [12]. In the DEFCs, ethanol is oxidized to carbon dioxide at the anode according to the reaction: CH3CH2OH+3H2O=2CO2 +12H+ +12e. The reaction is considered to be a combination of adsorption and electrochemical reaction on the anode surface [13,14]. Accordingly, because of the adsorption capacity of carbon, the later has been incorporated in many recently reported electrocatalytic materials [15–19]. In the field of electrochemical energy generating devices, cadmium is a pioneer metal; it shows good catalytic activities in various kinds of instruments [20,21]. The sol–gel process is a wet-chemical technique used for the fabrication of both glassy and ceramic materials. In this process, the sol (or solution) evolves gradually towards the formation of a gel-like network containing both a liquid phase and a solid one. Typical precursors are metal alkoxides, which undergo hydrolysis and polycondensation reactions to form an integrated network. The basic structure or morphology of the solid phase can range anywhere from discrete colloidal particles to continuous chain-like polymer networks. Some metal salts such as chloride, nitrate and acetates can be hydrolyzed and polycondensate to form the gel network. With those salts, using of a viscous polymer can enhance formation of the gel formulation. In this study, cadmium-doped cobalt nanoparticles enveloped in graphite shells are introduced as novel non precious catalyst for the ethanol electrooxidation. The introduced catalyst has been synthesized by simple sol–gel technique using poly(vinyl alcohol), cobalt acetate and cadmium acetate as precursors. Investigation of the electrocatalytic performance of the proposed materials indicated very good activity towards ethanol oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt (II) acetate tetra-hydrate (CoAc, 98% assay Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd, Japan), cadmium acetate dihydrate (CdAc, 99.0% assay, Sigma Aldrich), and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA, molecular weight=65,000g/mol, DC Chemical Co., Ltd, South Korea) were utilized without any further modification. Distilled water was used as a solvent. 2.2 Procedures To prepare CdAc/CoAc/PVA sol–gel, 22.5g PVA (10wt%), 5g of CoAc (20wt%) and 2.5g of CdAc (20wt%) aqueous solutions were well mixed, the final colloid has been stirred at 50°C for 5h. The well mixed gel was dried in two successive steps. First, the gel was dried under atmospheric pressure at 60°C for 24h, and then under high vacuum atmosphere at 80°C for 48h. The obtained hard material was crushed and grinded. The calcination process was carried out under argon atmosphere at 1atm and 750°C. Heating from the room temperature to 750°C was done within 5h, and then the temperature was fixed at 750°C for 5h. 2.3 Characterization Information about the phase and crystallinity was obtained by using Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku, Japan) with Cu Kα (λ =1.540Å) radiation over Bragg angle ranging from 10° to 100°. Normal and high resolution images were obtained with transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010, Japan) operated at 200kV equipped with EDX analysis. The surface composition was detected with an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS, AXIS-NOVA, Kratos Analytical, UK) with the following conditions: base pressure of 6.5×10−9 Torr, resolution (pass energy) of 20eV and scan step of 0.05eV/step. The electrochemical measurements were performed in a 1M KOH solution at room temperature. The measurements were performed on a VersaSTAT 4 (USA) electrochemical analyzer and a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell. A Pt wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode were used as the auxiliary and reference electrodes, respectively. All potentials were quoted with regard to the Ag/AgCl electrode. High purity Ar was used before and during measurements to deaerate the electrolyte in all measurements. 3 Results and discussion As aforementioned in the introduction section, some metals acetate can be gelled especially in presence of a proper polymer solution. Accordingly, the acetate salts were utilized; typically cobalt and cadmium acetates, PVA was utilized a polymeric matrix. Polycondensation can be explained as follows [22]: (1) where M is Co or Cd. The utilized precursors formed good gel which was dried, grinded and calcined as aforementioned in the experimental section. Among the various analytical techniques, X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) received the most confidence to investigate the composition of the crystalline materials. Fig. 1 displays XRD analysis pattern for the obtained powder after the proposed calcination process. The strong diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 44.35, 51.65, 75.95, 92.35 and 97.75° corresponding to (111), (200), (220) (311) and (222) crystal planes indicate the formation of cubic crystalline cobalt (JCDPS, card no. 15-0806). Formation of pure cobalt form calcination of cobalt acetate in an inert atmosphere was explained in details in other studies [23–25]. Additionally, the broad peak at 2θ of 26.3° corresponds to an experimental d spacing of 3.37Å indicating presence of graphite-like carbon (d (002), JCPDS; 41-1487). Fig. 2 displays the XPS analysis of the obtained powder. The survey scans were carried out to search for the presence of particular elements in the sample showed the presence of Co 3P3/2 (∼59eV) [26], C 1s (∼285eV) [27], O 1s and Cd 3d core levels. According to the XPS data, one can claim that the cadmium in the introduced powder is in the form of CdO. It can be seen in the inset that the Cd 3d region consists of the main 3d3/2 spin–orbit components at binding energies of 402 and 409eV, respectively [28,29]. Moreover appearance of the O 1s peak as shown in the second inset affirms formation of CdO, because the XRD analysis affirmed formation of cobalt metal. Maximum intensity is related to the carbon element as can be observed in the corresponding inset (C1s), it means that the synthesized nanoparticles have considerable amount of carbon. Moreover, from the intestines of Cd and Co peaks, it can be claimed that Cd content in the surface is higher than Co. Fig. 3 displays the TEM images of the obtained powder. As shown in the figures, metallic nanoparticles surrounded by graphite shell are obtained. The selected area electron pattern, as shown in the inset, demonstrates good crystallinity of the metallic nanoparticles. Moreover, from Fig. 3B, one can claim that the metallic nanoparticles are sheathed inside thin graphite layer. Enveloping the cobalt nanostructures in graphite shell was introduced by the same authors [23]. From the TEM results, one can claim that the thickness of the graphite shell is around 5nm. Fig. 4 reveals the IV plots for a thin film from the introduced material on the silicon substrate. Good electric conductivity is an important parameter for the electrocatalytic materials. Clearly, it can be observed that the IV plot resembles the metallic conductors with considerably low ohm resistance. Compared to nickel, pristine cobalt has low electrocatalytic activity because the former can be activated by forming electrochemically active compounds on the surface. For instance in case of nickel, NiOOH compound can be electrochemically synthesized on the surface which generate good electrochemical activity [30]. The cyclic voltammetric behaviour of cobalt and the introduced Cd-doped Co/C nanoparticles electrodes in 1M KOH solution are shown in Fig. 5 . Polarization was started by a potential scanning at a scan rate of 100mVs−1 from 800mV to 0mV (vs. Ag/AgCl reference electrode) in the cathodic direction and then the scan was reversed in the anodic direction back to 800mV. As shown in Fig. 5A, no redox peaks appear in case of pristine cobalt which may explain the corresponding low electrocatalytic activity. Fig. 5B displays the obtained results in case of utilizing the introduced nanoparticles. As shown in the figure, presence of carbon and cadmium strongly enhances the current density compared to the pristine cobalt. Appearing of redox peaks is an important finding can be observed in Fig. 5B. Considering that cobalt metal does not reveal any redox reactions (Fig. 5A), the appeared peaks in Fig. 5B can be assigned to CdO. According to our best knowledge, Cd-based materials were never used as electrodes in the direct alcohols fuel cells, however the nickel/cadmium batteries are well known electrochemical energy devices [31]. As aforementioned, the NiOOH represents the electoractive layer formed on the nickel surface. The active layer is formed at ∼580mV (vs. NHE) in accordance with the reaction [32–34]: (2) Ni ( OH ) 2 + OH ⇄ NiOOH + H 2 O + e Therefore, analogy to nickel, it can be claimed that cadmium oxide nanoparticles in the introduced electrocatalyst are subjected to following reaction: (3) CdO + OH ⇄ CdOOH + e Similar route of nickel is not applicable as pristine nickel converts to nickel hydroxide at the negative potential side (∼−650mV [30]) which is outside the utilized range in this study. Therefore, direct transformation of CdO to CdOOH (Eq. (3)) has high possibility. It is expected that CdOOH phase to be good electroactive material due to the lower interelectrode spacing that results in lower internal resistance and therefore better efficiency of the electrode [35,36]. It is noteworthy mentioning that, according to Pourbaix diagram [37], at high pH, cadmium oxide converts to cadmium hydroxide this supports the suggested reaction. Generally, the alcohol electrooxidation process is based on adsorption of the original reactants and the intermediates compounds, and then successive dissociation steps carry out. Typically, in case of ethanol dehydrogenation, the first step is the cleavage of OH bond, forming ethoxy species CH3CH2O. Further transformation of ethoxy species gives acetaldehyde CH3CHO, which then can be oxidized by numerous reactions, forming acetate ion CH3COO−, acetone CH3COCH3, crotonaldehyde CH3CHCHCHO, acetyl CH3CO, methane, other hydrocarbons, carbonate ion CO3 2−, CO and CO2 [38,39]. On the surface Pt, the efficiency for the electrooxidation of ethanol to CO2 is low due to incomplete dehydrogenation of the intermediate compounds [39]. The optimum dehydrogenation means releasing the maximum number of electrons (e.g. 12). In such a case, the CC bond is dissociated and the resulting C1 species are oxidized to CO2. Several elements were added to the conventional catalyst; Pt to improve the photocatalytic activity (e.g. Cu, Mn, Ru, Ni, Rh, Sn, etc. [38–40]). Generally, the main role of the dopant metals (M) is formation of MOH bond by dissociative adsorption of H2O on the catalyst surface, consequently the ethanol oxidation is distinctly enhanced. Therefore, the formed CdOOH in the introduced catalyst has an important function. Fig. 6 represents the cyclic voltammetry results for the Cd-doped Co/C, Pt/C (40%) and pristine Co NPs. As shown in the figure, the introduced electrocatalyst can successfully enhance ethanol oxidation. The oxidation process is observed during the positive potential. When the potential scanning is reversed, the strongly adsorbed OH is reduced with the potential lowering. Then ethanol oxidation occurs again, thus oxidation peaks are observed during negative potential scanning as shown in Fig. 6. The cyclic voltammograms (CV) data using Pt/C (40%) electrode are incorporated in Fig. 6. As shown in this figure, compared to the Pt/C, the introduced catalyst reveals high current density. Although Co has not observed role in the electrochemical reactions, it has very good contribution in enhancing the electrical conductivity of the introduced NPs (Fig. 4). Actually, Co-free Cd/C NPs were synthesized by the same procedure, the corresponding activity was very low (data not shown). The onset potential is the potential at which there exists a reaction pathway where all reaction steps have negative free energies. The onset potential indicates the electrode overpotential. In other words, it can be utilized to evaluate the efficacy of the electrocatalyst. Generally, more negative onset potential indicates high activity and less overpotential. The linear scan voltammograms for the ethanol oxidation in Fig. 6 indicates that the corresponding onset potential of the introduced material is ∼365mV (vs. Ag/AgCl, i.e. ∼585 vs. NHE). Moreover, the corresponding current density is high (70mA/cm2). The main reason behind increasing the onset potential is the OH and CO adsorped layer on the surface of the electrodes, this gas layer leads to overpotential [41]. Carbon monoxide accumulates on the surface of the electrode till further oxidation step to carbon dioxide. Adsorption of CO appears to take place with the formation of islands of adsorbate [42]; electroactivity appears to be restricted to the outsides of these islands. Accordingly, good catalytic activity is related with the rate of CO removal. Oxidation of the CO leads to appear a peak in the voltammogram at ∼550mV (vs. NHE) [43]. Generally, above 700mV, the surface is almost free of adsorped CO because of complete oxidation [44]. As shown in the obtained results, the aforementioned CO oxidation peak is not observed which indicates either instant oxidation and/or absence of CO as an intermediate compound. Considering that Co strongly enhances CO oxidation on Pt-Co catalyst [12], the first hypothesis can be understood. Moreover, presence of Cd may catalyze formation of CoOOH active layer (analogy to Eq. (1)) overcoming producing CO intermediate which supports the second hypothesis. Considering that the Co is relatively higher than Cd in the introduced catalyst, so the former should have distinct impact in the obtained high current density that further supports formation of CoOOH active layer. Concentrated ethanol solution is a targeted fuel in the DEFCs to reduce the volume. Increasing of ethanol can have negative influence on the current density, so each electrocatalyst corresponds to certain concentration. In this study, the ethanol concentration has been increased to investigate the influence of the solution concentration; Fig. 7 displays the obtained results. As shown in the figure, the onset potential is independent on the ethanol concentration. However, slight increase in the current density with increasing the ethanol concentration is observed. It is noteworthy mentioning that, more high concentration (>2M) revealed low current densities (data not shown), so it can be claimed that the optimum concentration lies within the introduced values. The effect of scan rate on the behaviour of ethanol oxidation at the introduced electrocatalyst was investigated (Fig. 8 ). It can be clearly seen in Fig. 8 that oxidation of the ethanol in the cathodic path is a scan rate dependent. In other words, increases the scan rate enhances the electrooxidation of the ethanol (Fig. 8B). To properly check the durability of the introduced NPs, constant voltage test was done at applied potential of 0.6V (Fig. 9 ). As shown in the figure, an initial current matching the corresponding value in the CV curves (Fig. 6) is observed. Later on, the current decay is relatively unnoticeable. It is noteworthy mentioning that, only one working electrode has been used in all the electrochemical analysis. Multiple use of the electrode did not affect the performance which supports the good stability of the introduced catalyst. The obtained good stability might be explained by the thin graphite layer enveloping the bimetallic nanoparticles (Fig. 3B). Overall, the present study introduces new class of electrocatalysts based on the transition metals to replace the conventional precious metals-based catalyst. The obtained performance strongly encourages completing the research in this new class of bimetallic catalysts. 4 Conclusion Calcination of well dried and finally grinded sol–gel composed of cobalt acetate, cadmium acetate and poly(vinyl alcohol) in argon atmosphere at 750°C leads to produce cadmium-doped cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated in graphite shell. The synthesized nanoparticles can be utilized as effective non precious catalyst in ethanol electro-oxidation. The corresponding current density and onset potential are very satisfactory. According to the results obtained from this study, the cost problem due to utilizing precious metals in the fuel cells can be overcome by more extensive research on the bimetallic transition metals nanostructures. coredata.dc:description: Novel electrocatalyst based on non precious metals (Co and Cd) is introduced to be used as anode in the ethanol fuel cells. Cd-doped Cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated in graphite shell have been synthesized using simple sol–gel technique. The introduced electrocatalyst can be prepared from a sol–gel composed of cadmium acetate, cobalt acetate and poly(vinyl alcohol) based on the polycondensation possibility of the acetates. Grinding and calcination in Ar atmosphere of the prepared gel leads to produce Cd-doped Co nanoparticles encapsulated in a thin graphite layer. High current density (70mAcm−2) and considerably low onset potential (∼585mV vs. NHE) were obtained when the synthesized nanoparticles have been exploited as electrocatalyst for ethanol (concentration 1M) oxidation in basic media (1M KOH). Considering that the introduced nanoparticles composed of non precious metals and the obtained electrochemical results are satisfactory, the introduced study might open new avenues to the cobalt-based nanostructures to be used as novel electrocatalysts in the fuel cells applications.
coredata.dc:title: Ethanol electro-oxidation using cadmium-doped cobalt/carbon nanoparticles as novel non precious electrocatalyst
